sect2.title: Contents
sect2.para: Most level 2 translations are related to &d-i; second stage.

In &d-i; jargon, the second stage is the part of &d-i; which occurs from the system reboot up to the Installation is finished screen followed by the first login: prompt. This stage is, technically speaking, the whole run of the base-config program.

All packages which interact with users during this second stage while a Debian base system is installed, with the default level for the asked questions (high priority installs in &d-i; jargon) are considered part of the level 2 of &d-i; localization.
This includes two packages maintained by the &d-i; team as well as a few other Debian packages:

Iso-codes and console-data packages material is indeed used in &d-i; first stage but including them in the level 1 of translation would be too confusingas these packages are not maintained by the &d-i; team. This is why they are considered part of the level 2.
Translators should translate these file in the same order they appear in this section.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The newt package is a library (whiptail) which includes widgets used by the most popular interface to the debconf software, the software involved in packages configuration steps. These widgets include the Yes or No widgets used by boolean templates, as well as the OK or Abort buttons text.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: No public revision control repository is available for this package so access through the translation statistics pages is the only way to get translation material for it:

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the newt package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: N/A

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The &base-config; package is the core of the second stage of the installation of a Debian system. It consists in a set of tasks which may be called from a general menu. Each of these tasks is responsible for a specific operation (users creation, email system configuration, etc.) Some of these tasks are directly part of &base-config;, some others are handled by separate packages (which translations are part of level 2 and level 3)

This package is, technically speaking, a regular Debian package. However, the package maintainer is the &d-i; team and the package is managed and developed the same way core &d-i; packages are managed. More precisely, all &d-i; translators have been granted a commit access to the &base-config; SVN repository.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: Translators should remember that using SVN is strongly encouraged as this is the only way for them to commit their own translations.
This package's l10n material is spread over two files. These are, by order of importance:

listitem.para: debian/po/templates.pot : screen shown to users while the program runs. These files are named debconf translations.
po/base-config.pot : messages displayed by the program. These files are named program translations.

sect3.para: Access to these files:

listitem.para: SVN access: &svn-base-config;, directory debian/po (debconf) and po (programs)

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: For the debconf translation, translators should copy the templates.pot file as &language;.po and work on this file, then add it to the repository and later commit the needed updates.
For the program translation, translators should copy the base-config.pot file as &language;.po and work on this file, then add it to the repository and later commit the needed updates.

In case SVN commits are absolutely impossible, these updates can be sent as bug reports against the base-config package (see for details) and mention whether the file is the debconf or program translation.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: In the debconf translation, the entries of type "text" are menu entries. Their length shouldn't exceed 65 characters. Menu entries must not include commas.

One string in the program translation uses Plural-Forms. Translators should use the appropriate Plural-Forms: header for their language (details about Plural Forms in gettext can be found in ). This string should also not end with a full stop as mentioned in comments.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The shadow package includes several core utilities for a Unix system (login, passwd...) as well as the root user password setting step and the creation of a non-privileged user.
It is installed and configured from base-config which triggers some of these operations and thus implies user input.

The programs (passwd, login and so on) are internationalized but this translation is not considered in level 2, but in level 4 (see ). The only level 2 translation is the debconf translation (user input screens).

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintenance team uses a SVN repository.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the shadow package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: Translators should be very careful when translating the shadow user interaction screens. The most important screen is the one asking for the root password. It should be kept short so that the screen fits on one screen. Jargon must be avoided (&d-i; is targeted to low skilled users and to Unix beginners). For instance, translators should try to keep the mention of root being the system administrator.

Another potential source of confusion are the screens asking about the newly created user real name and login name. The English version tries to be clear about what is what and translations should make this distinction very clear.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The &tasksel; package, called from base-config for each installation, proposes tasks to trigger the installation of complete sets of Debian packages. A task is a collection of several individual Debian packages all related to a specific activity.

This package is, technically speaking, a regular Debian package. However, the package maintainer is the &d-i; team and the package is managed and developed the same way core &d-i; packages are managed. More precisely, all &d-i; translators have been granted a commit access to the tasksel SVN repository.

Several tasks are related to localized environments. These tasks install packages that are likely to be useful when using Debian with the mentioned languages. The language tasks are automatically tagged for install when the given localized environment has been used with &d-i;.
Translators whose language does not currently have such task should provide one. See for details about this. Other translators should check the existing language task for their language.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: Translators should remember that using SVN is strongly encouraged as this is the only way for them to commit their own translations.
This package's l10n material is spread over three files. These are, by order of importance:

listitem.para: tasks/po/debian-tasks.pot: tasks descriptions translations. These files are named tasks translations.
debian/po/templates.pot : text of the screen shown to users. These files are named debconf translations.
po/tasksel.pot : messages displayed by the program. These files are named program translations.

sect3.para: Access to these files:

listitem.para: SVN access: &svn-tasksel;, directories tasks/po, debian/po and po

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: For the tasks translation, translators should copy the debian-tasks.pot file in tasks/po as &language;.po and work on this file, then add it to the repository and later commit the needed updates.
For the debconf translation, translators should copy the templates.pot file in debian/po as &language;.po and work on this file, then add it to the repository and later commit the needed updates.
For the program translation, translators should copy the tasksel.pot file in po as &language;.po and work on this file, then add it to the repository and later commit the needed updates.

In case SVN commits are absolutely impossible, these updates can be sent as bug reports against the tasksel package (see for details) and mention whether the file is the tasks, debconf or program translation.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: In the program translation file, "aptitude" is a program name and should not be translated.

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: A core &d-i; package (localechooser) uses country names and codes from the iso-codes package. The country name translations are taken from this package instead of being duplicated. These country names translations are likely to be used in other parts of the Debian operating system.
For this reason, translators need to translate the iso_3166.tab file in the iso-codes package (ISO-3166 is the standard for country (and other areas of specific geographic interest names and codes.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintainer uses a CVS repository.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the iso-codes package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: The ISO-3166 list includes all countries, regions are area of specific geopolitical interest in the world. Translators should be aware that this translation is far from being a trivial work and may very quickly turn into some deep and complicated political difficulties. The original English names are those used officially by the relevant countries to design themselves. Please make your best for staying as neutral and close to these names as possibles. Some countries Foreign Affairs (or equivalent) ministries keep lists of country names translations in their own languages.
For each country, the standard defines a short name (to be used in lists) and a long name which is the official complete name of the country.
If in doubt, translators should contact the iso-codes package maintainer : iso-codes@packages.debian.org.

The ISO-639 (language names) and ISO-4217 files (currencies names) can also be translated. However, this is a very tedious task which may turn to be very difficult (translating language names is even more difficult than translating country names).

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: A core &d-i; package (kbd-chooser) uses keyboard names (and mapping files) from the console-data package. Thus, in order to get it completely translated, translators need to translate console-data debconf templates.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintainer uses a SVN repository.

listitem.para: &url-level2-po-link;, console-data_debian_po_&language;.po. console-data_debian_po_en.po is also useful (see below)

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the console-data package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: Translators must translate the keyboard layout names to real names. For this, they should look at the en.po file (which is available at &console-data-en;) as this file includes English translations of the original keyboard map names.

For instance de-latin1-nodeadkeys is translated to "German" there, so the translation should only be for German (in that specific case, the nodeadkeys part is not translated: there are technical reasons for this : this is why using the English translation as a reference is highly recommended).

sect3.title: Package description
sect3.para: The exim4 package installs the Exim Mail Transport Agent (MTA). It is installed by default on all newly installed Debian GNU/Linux systems as Exim has always been the default Debian MTA (even if other MTA may be used and installed later by the system administrator).
It is installed and configured from base-config which triggers some of its configuration steps and thus involves user input.

sect3.title: Files location and access methods
sect3.para: This package is a regular Debian package. The package maintainer currently does no use any public CVS or SVN repository.

sect3.title: Updating/Adding translations
sect3.para: Translations should be reported as bugs against the exim4 package.

sect3.title: Specific recommendations
sect3.para: The translation of some exim4 user input screens may be tricky.

More particularly, the screen giving the choice between all possible type of configurations is not easy to handle for translators. Each individual choice contains a description of what this choice means : this must be kept shorter than 72 characters, otherwise, the display will be cut on most screens.

Translators should also try to keep the long description of this specific screen as short as possible and still be clear and avoid jargon. This screen will be shown on every installation, even default ones (which are very likely to be used by low skilled users).
